answers.text:
Here are some examples from the Town of Fishers, Indiana:
GIVE Committee (Generosity, Involvement, and Volunteerism by Employees)
PERforM Initiative (Professional Employees Reaching for More)
FishersFirst Initiative
Intranet Messaging
Employee Newsletter
Town Manager Quarterly Briefings for Employees
Employee Task Forces
Employee Surveys
Public Service Recognition Week
Employee Holiday Luncheon
Halloween Department and Individual Costume Contests (Also a Trick or Treat site for small kids)
Touch-a-Truck Community Event
Town Government Academy
Citizen Police Academy

answers.author: Michael Repas
answers.text:
Having looked for a few more options, I have several articles and documents from the Knowledge Network which might also help:
-Employee Engagement plan from Olathe, Kansas
http://icma.org/en/icma/knowledge_network/documents/kn/Document/20301/Creating_Engagement_and_Results_through_Online_Employee_Development_Planning__Olathe_KS 
-Leadership and Employee Engagement
http://icma.org/en/icma/knowledge_network/documents/kn/Document/1165/Leadership_and_Employee_Engagement
Here are a few more resources for you:
In the United Kingdom, the city of Birmingham has an excellent, integrated program in place for employee engagement, called BEST (Belief, Excellence, Success, Trust)
-Their website has some excellent information: http://www.birminghambest.co.uk/aboutbest 
-The BEST program also makes extensive use of a Twitter account, which provides constant feedback and encouragement to all their employees (nearly 600 employees follow the updates from it, so it clearly has a major impact).  Check it out here: http://twitter.com/birminghambest 
I hope this helps!
